Orientation Console: "Most residents arrive after their third Saturday of edging. You are in safe hands."

Intake accepted. Your lawn did not fail you; it was designed to consume your weekends, your groundwater, and eventually your conversational range.

Field Protocol unlocked: Phase one is social camouflage. We replace twelve square feet at a time, introduce native groundcover, and leave one precise strip of conventional grass so no one asks questions until week six.

Typical timeline: 14 weeks from mowing loop to pollinator loop.
Certified in municipal code interpretation across 31 counties.

Field Notes: Week 0 to Week 8

We opened with a neighborhood listening walk at dusk. Sprinklers hissed in stereo. Three residents held hoses like ceremonial objects while discussing rainfall deficits. At 7:43 PM, participant #214 whispered, "I think I only own this yard because my father owned this yard." We marked that as the turning point.

[LOG 02] Replace south-facing turf with low-water sedge matrix. [LOG 03] Introduce sign: "SOIL RECOVERY IN PROGRESS" to reduce peer concern. [LOG 04] Redirect Saturday labor toward porch breakfast and unstructured reading. [LOG 05] Track hummingbird return. Resident tears noted. Positive trajectory.

Hover each internal memo to view the line that used to stay redacted during first consultations.

Memo A: Compliance

"Maintain one familiar visual anchor near curb edge."

We call it the comfort strip so neighbors feel the transition as design, not rebellion.

Memo B: Family Script

"When relatives ask why the lawn changed, avoid debate language."

Say: We updated the yard to match local climate and now Saturdays belong to us again.

Memo C: Block Dynamics

"Do not underestimate copied behavior on short streets."

One visible conversion often triggers two more by the next tax season.
